tips.Tips: Aging (blood pressure tends to rise with age).
Unhealthy diet high in salt, saturated fats, and sugars.
Lack of physical activity and a sedentary lifestyle.
Chronic stress and high levels of stress hormones.
Dietary choices, including processed and fast foods.
Chronic use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
Certain dietary supplements like ephedra and licorice.
Chronic use of decongestants and some over-the-counter cold medications.
High levels of stress from work, personal life, or emotional factors.
Hormonal changes during menopause in women.
High intake of processed or canned foods.
A diet lacking in essential nutrients like calcium, magnesium, and potassium.
Excessive use of oral contraceptives in some cases.
Inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis.
Chronic use of certain recreational drugs, like cocaine or amphetamines.
Chronic use of non-prescription pain relievers.
Neurological conditions affecting blood pressure regulation.
Hormonal fluctuations during the menstrual cycle.
Gout and high uric acid levels.
Use of herbal supplements that can affect blood pressure.
Thyroid disorders, such as hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism.
Chronic use of nasal decongestant sprays.
Conditions that affect the adrenal glands, like Cushing's syndrome.
Certain chronic respiratory conditions, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
Use of oral steroids for an extended period.
Chronic use of certain medications, like NSAIDs, cyclosporine, or tacrolimus.
Mental health conditions like anxiety or depression.
Chronic use of oral contraceptives containing high doses of estrogen.
Some autoimmune disorders affecting blood vessels, like vasculitis.
Excessive caffeine intake from energy drinks or pre-workout supplements.
Chronic use of medications that constrict blood vessels.
Chronic use of bronchodilators for respiratory conditions.
Conditions that affect the central nervous system.
Pheochromocytoma, a rare adrenal gland tumor.
